text: [Music]
venezuela's leader Hugo Chavez rose from
poverty to hold unrivaled influence in a
country with some of the world's largest
oil reserves this is C moral medal for
the New York Times I cover Chavez for
five years from 2006 when I arrived in
Caracas as bureau chief until 2011
Chavez was a complicated man intensely
loved or hated in Venezuela he was seen
by some is almost a messianic leader
both in Venezuela and elsewhere in Latin
America who thought he could be
reelected indefinitely wielding power in
the tradition of Latin America's
caballos or strongmen
he had a televangelists gift for oratory
and sought out media attention indulging
in hours long appearances on state TV
but he was also intensely private he
obsessed with what he thought were plots
to oust him he called his critics at
home traitors in aimed some of his most
bitter attacks at Washington LA pretends
young harmonica del imperio leha North
Americanos own and Yahoo la super
Valencia me ma del pesci uma√±a Chavez
did everything he could to counter the
US government from personal insult
el Senor Presidente de los Estados
Unidos Akiyama el diablo to forging
close ties with western foes like iran's
Ahmadinejad Libya's Qaddafi and Syria's
ash are al Assad but it was his
friendship with Cuba's Fidel Castro that
mattered most
Chavez saw in Castro a survivor and
mentor and Castro son Chavez a new type
of populist leader who could help Cuba a
sort of cross-pollination ensued Caracas
providing Havana with oil while Cuba
sent its human capital to Venezuela
including doctors and military advisors
a former soldier who led Venezuela's
failed 1992 military coup loss of eppy
volcano plant demos no fueron la la la
la rocca be done Chavez was
democratically elected
in 1998 area he had promised the country
a revolution and he delivered one
removing the old order in using the
country's oil revenues to boost spending
on education and health care many poor
Venezuelans adore him feeling included
in the political system for the first
time but others saw his government is
highly dysfunctional Caracas once one of
Latin America's most prosperous cities
took on a dystopian feel with one of the
highest murder rates in the world
hospitals lack basic medical supplies
food shortages plagued the city and one
luxury skyscraper the Tower of David
which was built for bankers has become a
home for thousands of squatters one of
the most telling moments in my time
covering Chavez was a trip to the Andes
with him and the American actor Sean
Penn this man were the visceral
connection to the poor seemed to bask in
the luxury of his presidency as he
roamed his spacious air bus complete
with a private lounge the cold fear in
madam likes attention to more obsess a
dough as his health faded beginning in
2011 Chavez traveled to Cuba for
treatment he would disappear for weeks
turning Venezuela into a place ruled by
rumor and speculation about his health
his legacy remains memorialized in the
murals that dot the many slums of
Caracas the myth of Chavez often
prevailed over the contradictions
inherent in the man himself
you
